s.text: The same seems to be true of Italians and probably others.
Many Jews find a trace of their roots in Israel.
The shtetl in Belarus that my father left to come to America as a boy, over 100 years ago, certainly bears no traces of my origins--if it still exists.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
It is a testament to openness and democracy in America that so many of us want this connection and succeed in achieving it.
Perhaps because the world changes so rapidly that for many people, the real roots no longer exist.
Perhaps because the world changes so rapidly that for many people, the real roots no longer exist.
The Irish like to go back to the Old Sod and see the conditions in which their grandparents lived and perhaps meet relatives they had not known before.
But that was a long, long time ago, and the connection grows faint.
But that was a long, long time ago, and the connection grows faint.
But that was a long, long time ago, and the connection grows faint.

Would a person whose family had lived in France or Japan for three generations come to identify himself with the French or the Japanese culture of 200 years ago as if his family had been a part of it?
